title: Section 377 in The Indian Penal Code, 1860
summary: Defines 'unnatural offences' under Indian law. In the 2018 Navtej Singh Johar case, the Supreme Court partially struck down Section 377, decriminalizing consensual homosexual acts.

title: Section 386 in The Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973
summary: Describes the appellate powers of the court, including revision of sentences under Sections 377 and 378 CrPC.

title: Section 394 in The Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973
summary: States that every appeal under Sections 377 or 378 CrPC shall abate on the appellant’s death.

title: Section 389 in The Indian Penal Code, 1860
summary: Punishment for threatening someone with false accusation under Section 377 IPC to commit extortion.

title: Section 377 in The Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973
summary: Allows the state to appeal against inadequate sentencing by a trial court.

title: Section 388 in The Indian Penal Code, 1860
summary: Deals with extortion by threatening to accuse someone of an offence punishable under Section 377 IPC.

title: Navtej Singh Johar vs Union Of India on 6 September, 2018
summary: Supreme Court landmark judgment that read down Section 377 IPC, decriminalizing consensual same-sex relationships among adults.

title: Section 393 in The Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973
summary: Specifies conditions for appeal proceedings, including applicability to appeals under Section 377 CrPC.

title: Section 385 in The Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973
summary: Outlines appellate procedure when the appeal is not dismissed summarily—relevant to Section 377 cases.
